review_body: I had booked four rooms for my team and requested for early check in but when I reached hotel , early check in was refused . I offered to pay for the early check in and they demanded two and a half times the normal room rent . I came at around 11 30 AM with my team and for only two three hours early check in , I had to pay for two rooms around 53000 yen . This amount is almost three times the tariff available on any of Hotel booking websites . I had no option but to take two rooms on exorbitant tariffs . Very bad experience .

Stayed for 3 nights. The theme/decor of the Hotel is very chic and it was extremely clean. The room is a bit small but it was functional.The area is very clean. Also there is a convenience store just downstairs.

I stayed at the Mitsui Garden Nihombashi for 3 nights in February while on a business trip to Tokyo. The staff are all wonderfully polite and helpful, and the hotel is very clean and has a nice bar and restaurant. Unfortunately, my room had no desk to work from, and the TV programming had only one channel in English. Would recommend a global vote brand in lieu of this hotel.

Stayed for two nights in a superior king with Tokyo Tower view. Room was in excellent condition. Sizewise ok for two people but not spacious as all rooms in Tokyo so far. Friendly staff, the Japanese bath is a highlight.Didn’t try breakfast.The hotel bar didn’t look very appealing, there’s more in the neighbourhood.Great location, metro and rail directly or under the hotel, Tokyo Station even in walking distance.

Stayed there for 9 days with my 2 girls. We booked a triple room which was around 26 sqm which I suppose is a standard sized room. But due to the fact that they needed to squeeze in 3 beds, the room was pretty tight for the 3 of us. Check in was pretty smooth, the receptionist can speak a little bit of English, and even those who don't will try their best to explain things as clear as possible. Room is clean, with sufficient amenities provided. Best thing is that they provide a set of pyjamas for each guest, so for those who is staying longer stays and want to keep the luggage light, you don't need to worry about bringing pyjamas. No bathrobes, but that's not a real problem for us. One thing about the longer stay is that there is no coin operated washing machine/ dryer. So we had to bring sufficient clothes to change for our 9 days there. Hope this can improve in the future.The best thing is the public bath. Although it's "public", but if you go at the right hour, there is usually only 3 or 4 other people in the bath at any one time. Also was convenient for us as we didn't need to wait for the use of the room bathroom to take a bath and can just do it at the public bath which has full shower amenities, including lockers. After the bath, one can use the massage chairs for some relaxation. The hotel is directly connected to the train station of Mitsuhoshimae and Shin-Nihombashi. There is no need to come out from the station at all, but the exit is quite hidden and you may easily miss it, so we lugged our luggage up the exit staircase on the first day. Do ask the hotel staff where the exit is, for convenience. There is also a lift that is near the exit that connects to the train station. Very convenient. The station is only 2 stops fro Ginza and Tokyo Station. Very well connected. But if you like to stay in a lively area, this is not it. The streets are practically empty most of the time, espeically after sunset. There are a couple of malls nearby - Coredo, Mitsukoshi, Yuito, but they are selling more of the upmarket stuff. So if you want to have a bit of night time vibrance, you would need to take a train down to the next stops.

friendly ,efficient mid sized hotel. excellent location ,quiet, upmarket area of Tokyo for the discerning guest. Five minutes walk from the tube and five minutes by taxi to Tokyo main line. By no means five star however more than competent in every way. Pleasant helpful staff and nice relaxed breakfast area. Would say this is excellent value by japan standards. room was small but adequate but tranquility and quietness was biggest plus.highly recommendable.

This is one of the best hotels I have ever stayed in! The staff are so helpful and respectful. The service is amazing! Rooms are a little small but they’re certainly efficient! I highly recommend this hotel!

Modern well appointed hotel. Room was 20 sq m and well thought out so felt bigger. Shower only (no bath) but a good one. There is a bath-house for guest use open until late if you need a soak. I asked for a quiet room and it was silent! Downside was no view - just the side of the next building, but suited me. Stayed 4 nights and never disturbed. There is a JR station one stop to Tokyo station next to the hotel and many more transport options nearby. Loads of excellent dining options for any budget close by. Opposite the Mandarin which is one or the worlds greatest hotels, but value for money the Mitsui smashes it.

I stayed at this hotel for 4 nights last week whilst i was on a business trip. It clearly is targeted at the business traveller. Overall, the hotel is great but its' location ticks all the boxes. There is a train station attached to the hotel and this is a plus. The rooms are very compact, much smaller than a European standard (but housekeeping does a good job).There are 2 elements that are missing in the hotel : It does not have a gym and this is a must for a business traveller. The breakfast focuses on the Asian client and get very monotonous as it didn't change over the 4 days i stayed there.Staff are pleasant but would need to improve in their English skills before the Tokyo Olympics. Would I go stay here again ? Yes, of course.

Very well situated, modern and comfortable. The staff are very friendly and helpful they cannot do enough for you. We really enjoyed our stay and the late checkout of 12 midday was extremely helpful as we had a late flight home.

We are staying in the hotel right now. We are in room 1106 (see pictures to give you an idea). Room size is not large by American standards but if you ever stayed in Manhattan - you will find the room size more than adequate and you will be amazed by the multiple small ways they utilize every little square inch of the room. There is a large bed, great shower and bathtub, separate small room with toilet. All brand new and very efficient. Complimentary water, tea and kettle in the room as well as a small fridge. Plenty of outlets both for plugs and some for USB. They give you what they call “night clothing (basically pajamas) and slippers that you wear to the public bath (more about it a bit later). Cleaning is superb, change of towels etc plus change of pajamas. Great shampoo and conditioner in large pump bottles in the room. Separate cute “living room” area which we used to plan our day and also work a bit. Now to the public bath. If you ever went to a Korean bath in the states - the public bath in this hotel is basically the locker room facilities in one of those high end NYC Korean baths. A large hot pool that can fit probably 20 people and an area with small chairs, mirrors and showers to shave, brush your teeth, wash your head etc. it’s open at 6 am. Closes during the day and than open again in the afternoon until 1 (!!!). We use it every day. Sometimes in the morning and at night. You will love how you can relax after walking all day. Food: we skipped breakfast the first day, but went the second day. The price is about $25 per person. It’s not cheap. You can find cheaper in Tokyo. But this is a 4 star hotel by local standards and its Tōkyō. The quality of food is great. I posted pictures of the buffet. Has both Japanese and western options. Juices, espresso machine, freshly made omelets , bacon, sausage etc. as well as multiple traditional Japanese options. Definitely enough to justify the price. We will probably not eat there everyday, but not because of lack of quality or price. Just because we want someVariety :) Area:12 min walk to Tokyo station Multiple subway lines within 1-5 min walk from the hotel.7/11 in the building 24/7 and a great 24/7 sushi restaurant within 15 min walking distance. Price: if you are ok with the $150-250 range you are looking at this hotel in the first place. We are staying for 5 nights at about $840 total including all fees etc.
user_name:
ULS77
New York City, New York

review_body: We choose "Mitsui Garden Hotel Nihonbashi Premier" for our stay in Tokyo "downtown" (if we can call it that way), position is strategic getting pretty fast to the Tokyo Station, Ginza area, Chiyoda, Akihabara. Nearby there a metro station and a JR station (Kanda). Location is very quiet, rooms are very good (small for the western habits, big for the Japanese ones). Staff very supporting whenever needed. A plus the onsen in the hotel, to relax when tired because of the fatiguing tourism/shopping ;)

Rooms are extremely small, no space for luggage nor a desk for work. Room fees need to be prepaid and not able to get a refund. Reception is extremely inexperienced and slow. With the price they charge, there are many (better) options to choose from.

Train station is just around the corner, moving around is not much of an issue. 7-11 just downstairs hence it’s very convenient.We arrived early and was hoping to check in earlier but check in was strictly at 3pm which was fine with us as We were aware of this prior to booking.Room was cosy, space maximised, separate WC, bath and sink helps to speed up preparation time. Amenities were decent and replenished with a new bag daily.

I visited last month for 4 nights, fresh from the airport i arrived at 11am and was not able to check in until 2.30pm unless i paid for an additional night at a cost of $150? I declined their awful offer and asked if i could leave my luggage and grab a shower in their Onsen... This was not allowed either.The room was very stylish, great amenities and the Onsen is a lovely perk. However, i was staying solo and attempted to bring back a friend for a nightcap and we were stopped by reception, the whole situation was awful and i wouldnt wish it on anyone else. I paid the same rate as a double occupancy and didnt have breakfast inc therefore i should be entitled to have a friend visit. However, the hotel doesnt no permit visitors to bedrooms. It was weird. I wouldnt recommend solo travellers stay here.

I can highly recommend this hotel. It has a fantastic location and it is easy to get to the local train station. There are many nice restaurants nearby. The hotel seems very new and clean. It has a very nice bath.

Nice chic boutique hotel which is clean, comfy and cosy. It is conveniently located one stop away from Tokyo Station (with basement connection to the Nihonbashi Station), and huge shopping malls across the road with 100s of shops, restaurants and cafes. Pleasant and soothing fragrance throughout the lobby with their in-house aroma scent which makes you feel like you’re in a spa. It also offers complimentary public bath facilities for hotel guests.

***Hotel which seems much more. New & clean facilities along with excellent & flexible service. Some misunderstanding at booking was handled with perfection. Last but not least, excellent location. High recommendation!

Great city hotel with nice onsen and good rooms. staff are very friendly and a particular thank you to Mr. Ryuta K. from reception, who arranged that a hotel where we had stayed before sent us some items that we had forgotten.

We were very happy with the hotel, and the location - so near some great ally type restaurants, and near the Emperor Gardens as well only 20 minute walk. Rooms are stylish, roomy, nice amenities, and well done. We've stayed in many hotels in Japan and find the beds usually very hard and uncomfortable, but here - they were great.Price paid was reasonable and hard to see a better value compared to others we have stayed at in Japan. Staff was great... as they usually are in Japan :)Highly recommended!

The hotel is nice and clean with wonderful bed and nice hot bath. Conveniently with few stations around the hotel. Located at business district. The only lack of is surrounding food. Definitely will go back to this hotel.

Stayed here 2nights in a double bed comfort room. The room was clean but not spacious, we found it difficult to find floor space to open our suitcase on or find space to store luggage without them becoming a fire escape hazard. It was a shame that unlike other hotels we stayed in (double rooms do tend to be small in Japan) there was no facility to store cases under the bed.The blind in the room wasn't a black out blind so 4am the light shone through which was not welcomed!We didn't pay extra for breakfast, glad we didn't given others reviews. It is much cheaper and very easy to find cafes or family mart/seven elevens to purchase food in/from. Venues in and around the main train station are very good.Didn't find the facility was value for money and wished we had stayed in a more local owned venue that would have been the same size room, same room facilities plus breakfast for much less.

We've booked 2 rooms for 10nights making this our base for Tokyo visit. We couldn't have made a better decision. The rooms are really big even compared to hotels in cities like Paris, Milan or London. Official ranking of the hotel is 3* but it's due for it not having a co ference facilities. The rooms are dedicated Italy 4* having all you might need, even including a pyjama and socks. Breakfast is very Japaneese style with great variety of delicious dishes.For more European experience you can always find sausages, bacon, croissants and pain au chocolate. The hotel also has Sento, public bath, which you can enjoy daily till midnight. And last but not the least it is perfectly located with several stations 5 to 10 min walking distance.

This is a very new hotel that occupies the 9th to 15th floors of is building. The lobby on the 9th floor is very modern. The room had a king size bed and was a bit bigger than the usual very compact Japanese hotels. But we did pay extra for this of room. Really nice furnishings, great shower and we had an excellent view. The staff on the front desk are very friendly and helpful. There is an onsen which I used twice and luckily had it all to myself. Also very modern and nice. The hotel is right next to the Mitsukoshi-Mae on the Ginza line on the metro so really easy to get about. Also near Shin Nihombashi on the JR Yamanote line which is 2 stops from the main Tokyo train station.

We spent six nights at this good hotel , nicely located in an excellent quiet area in Tokyo , the service was excellent, the concierge were very helpful and very polite and friendly, like most people in Japan , very clean all around, I would not hesitate to go back when ever the occasion arises, breakfast was ok , it catered more to the Japanese clients with a big variety, but not for others,

We stayed here for a vacation. The quality of the rooms is excellent and well appointed. Even though the rooms are compact it had all the features we needed. Excellent staff service, English is OK. You can opt for the breakfast buffet or find a nice little Western-style cafe at the nearby metro station. Travel was very easy to access via the nearby metro and a few stops from Ginza and Ueno. We strolled to the Imperial Gardens - 25 min walk.

Modern hotel in a nice area like Nihombashi.Bus stop and underground very comfortable in front of the hotel.Nice hall with 2 outdoor areas, but that one with balcony and seats always closed during my 3 days stay, I didn’t understand why.The staff is polite but doesn’t speak English well, when you seat in the hall area they always ask if you need check in or anything else, maybe I’m wrong but the feeling is that they don’t like you seat there for long time.I booked a comfort room of 20 sqm but my room seems to be not over 15 sqm, really small, I can’t imagine the smaller ones.I asked where were the stairs to access to our floor room, but they told me not available, only by lift , but this is not acceptable (also in term of safety) then my wife never like use lift because she is claustrophobic, but was the only way.You have also to use 2 different lifts, from the ground floor to your room, really uncomfortable.TV transmits only Japanese channels, neither CNN or BBC. No Sat channels.Exchange rate not convenient through reception.Wi-Fi a bit slow.

Stayed for our first time in Tokyo and really enjoyed this hotel. The onsen was great, the beds were very comfortable and the hotel location was great for getting around. Definitely recommend this hotel for any type of stay in Tokyo.

Our stay at the Mitsui Garden Hotel Nihombashi was exceptional. The staff were incredibly helpful to the point of all first floor staff running with us to get us a taxi and helping us with our luggage so as not to miss our train. Everything is super clean and new. They have an assortment of amenities such as slippers, fabric freshner in the closet, etc., and provide water bottles daily. We had a triple room and all 4 (children 6 or younger can sleep for free in the room) of us slept comfortably. The onsen facilities are great and the women's facilities have massage chairs. It is open from 6-9 AM and from 3PM-1 AM. It is crowded in the afternoon and evening, but the mornings are sparsely attended. We did not eat in the restaurants, so we cannot provide a review there. We purchased breakfast items from 7 eleven on the first floor. Getting to the metro station was easy and there are several lines in the area. Tokyo station is close by, but if you have kids and luggage as us you may want to get a taxi to the hotel. Overall, I would equate this hotel to a well run Westin hotel in the US.

Love this hotel. It is new, clean and service is excellent. The staff will try their best to make the guest feel welcomed. Room size is already larger than the typical Japanese hotel at this price point. The Japanese bath was a nice touch; largely because some of the rooms do not come with a bathtub. This was not a major concern for us. Comfortable bed with pocket springs for a better night sleep.

Superb location, directly connected to the subway station and very close to the center of the city. The room had all the essential amenities, and mine had a view of the skytree even. The air-conditioning can be adjusted flexibly, and is cool enough in March. Loved the hot bath. There were massage chairs as well in the changing rooms. Great way to relax after a long day! High recommend to anyone visiting Tokyo.

Right next to two metro stations. Clean rooms and big for Tokyo. Good amenities in room. We didn't eat or drink at hotel. The hotel was a little cold in atmosphere/service. Temperature of hotel was very hot.

Stayed a few nights for business. Hotel is easily accessible by Shin-Nihonbashi train station. Despite the very strict 3pm check-in time, the hotel is nicely decorated, and the room is very comfortable. The Japanese style breakfast is wonderful. Lots of small dishes to choose from. The common baths on the lobby level are a nice touch. Not an onsen but very good for relaxing after a day of business. Very polite and helpful staff.

We were stuck an extra night in Tokyo due to the typhoon shutting down the Shinkansen lines, so we booked this hotel last minute. It’s a beautiful hotel, the foyer etc is stunning. The service was excellent, providing proper Japanese care and attention. I would very highly recommend staying here!

The hotel is located about 10 minutes walkway from the Ginza shopping area, about 15 minutes from the Tokyo train station. From this point of view quite good. There is furthermore a subway station beside the hotel which can connect you to the Narita airport. Convenient.The lobby of the hotel is in the 9th floor and to enter the rooms you need the room card. The hotel rooms are a bit bigger than the standard japanese hotel rooms. Clean and well organized. The bath resp. shower is separated from the toilet, which is good, because the shower is not the typical bath tub shower. Bath tub and shower separated but in the same room. All necessary items for daily shower and so on are available. The only thing missing is a desk. So working is a bit difficult in the rooms.The hotel employees are friendly so far we can communicate. The English of the employees is not very good. The employees in the breakfast room are not so friendly and sometimes take plates away right after you finish. A bit strange.The breakfast is not so good. Mainly Japanese food. Less international food like toast or bread. A hotel like this should have international breakfast. Instead they offer small tiny cups with some pickles or so inside. Breakfast has to be improved a lot.All in all the hotel is good for a short stay in Tokyo especially due to the close distance to the train station. Also for shopping in the Ginza area. Breakfast is not good, needs to be improved. Price-performance-ratio could be better, but Tokyo is a big city and more expensive.

See previous review for which Metro exits are the closest. The hotel is right on top of one exit so it’s super easy to walk underground and not get wet (as would have happened to me one evening) all the way from the Metro. I booked room only and wanted a location close to Tokyo Station. It turned out to be a 15-min walk at ground level. it took longer to walk underground as there were too many distractions (food, restaurants!). The hotel is in a business area but it’s a bustling one and there’s plenty of food available nearby in all the underground basement areas of buildings and other hotels. The room was clean (except some bits of dust which was overlooked), bed was comfy, shower only, lovely coffee available in the room. Best thing for me was the blackout blind. The room stayed in darkness when it was closed so we got full nights’ sleep (good for jet lag). Since we had room only we had little interaction with staff, speaking to them only during checking in and checking out. The reception is on 9th floor but the staff don’t step towards the lift to greet anyone.

The hotel is easily accessible from exit 1 & 3 of Shin Nihonbashi station and exit A10 of Mitsukoshi mae station. Through the underground passages, one can be protected from the freezing wind. There are restaurants right at the exits/entrances. Many other local restaurants are also within walking distance. A reception is located on the ground floor while the actual lobby is located on the 9th floor, similar design to that of Mitsui Garden Hotel in Nagoya. A public bath is on the same floor while the hotel rooms are located from 10th floor up. Breakfasts were mainly served with small Japanese dishes. There were also rice and congee but I was not able to locate any natto and raw egg which were usually served in breakfast. The purpose built triple room is a bit small. It's like replacing the 'sofa area' of a twin room with another single bed. The bathroom is great except that there is not much place for placing your cloths and towel without getting wet by the overhead shower so one needs to leave them on a rail on the outside face of the door. The toilet is separate from the bathroom. There is an air purifier in the room. The hotel staffs are of high quality.

The hotel is very well presented in a simple and elegant manner from the reception to the hotel room. The room is very spacious with a large bathroom area and comfortable bed. The amenities in the room are that of a higher class establishment. I would recommend staying here if you are looking around the Nihonbashi area.

Stayed 1 night on way from Vancouver to Sapporo.No complaints. Location, room, public bath, checkin etc. all very good. Didn't try the breakfast.But nothing stands out as exceptional. Not sure what makes it premier.

The hotel is in great location, right off 1 exit of Shin Nihonbashi station. It’s a new hotel and very close to all eating and shopping at Coredo shopping mall and Mitsukoshi department store. The room was a bit small for two people with two mid-size luggage, but manageable. We did not have any issues with this. The beds were comfortable, room clean, the vanity area was a bit tight but not too bad. We hardly used the shower room in the room as we took advantage of its spa nightly. The hotel concierge seemed to us a bit lack of experience. Among 4 hotels we stayed in this eating trip to Japan, this hotel was the only one could not make advanced reservation for us prior to our arrival. Other than this, it’s still a good hotel to stay in Nihonbashi for nearby shopping at department stores.

The hotel is located on top of the subway Mitsukoshi-Mae station and also has direct JR line access. However, getting up to the hotel itself, which is on the 9th floor of the building, involves a series of escalators and two elevators. Not easy to get to, and rooms are small. Might be worth the stay if you find a deal, but I would've rather spent the money in a more tourist-friendly location. The surrounding area is full of office buildings and corporate centers which pretty much go dead after the workday. Breakfast wasn't worth the $27 price tag so didn't opt for it. The public bath is a nice touch! Overall, was good for a perceived sense of luxury and access to trains BUT failed on practicalities essential to Tokyo tourists.

Very small rooms, and tiny everything. The rates are quite reasonable. Nice breakfast. The location is good. We can walk to the office building for our meetings. There is a big department store right cross the street.

Centrally located in the Nihonbashi area where you are walking distance or a metro train away. Loved the hospitality,service and professionalism of every staff members we encountered during our stay.Room is clean and daily housekeeping available. Buffet breakfast is Japanese style and limited continental options available. Access to the metro is easy. Request for a map and take the elevator to the basement and prepare to get lost.Highly recommended.

Hotel has a zen modern design. Stylish deco on 1F and 9F. Room corridors are sleek and smells good. Public bath is not warm enough. Heater in room works very well. Good location near mitsukoshimae station. Delicious cold tea & 3 choices of tofu offered for breakfast.

Nice and new but be advised cleaning is limited. Staying here for 2 nights and my room wasn’t cleaned after being out for the full day. All I got was an apology by the front desk and the manager on duty. Particularly disappointed being a foreign traveler as we wanted to rest a bit in the evening.

We enjoyed staying at this new hotel, our first time in Tokyo. It’s in a good position, directly above the subway, a convenience store 50metres away & shops 5minutes walk. As westerners we loved the Japanese breakfast - the best! A nice surprise was a free drink in the bar downstairs for hotel guests.

Good location a short taxi ride from the train station (or about a 15 minute walk). Lots of restaurants and shopping nearby. The hotel restaurant was great for a traditional Japanese breakfast.New hotel with beautiful rooms and all of the little extras that you might want provided. Japanese bath was lovely. Great staff who went above and beyond. I wish we could have stayed longer than 3 days.

Because it is brand new all the decor was unsullied. In time not sure whether the choices will last well. Some other design features were impractical: the black out curtain was behind the net curtain, so in order to access it you have to draw open the net. It would work better in reverse. The mirror above the basin has very little lighting for shaving and other requirements. The room, (a superior twin "corner" room) was typical of Japanese business hotels - very small - and it was difficult to accommodate ourselves and two suitcases. Did not use the restaurant or bar facilities, but both looked very inviting. There are many restaurants in the immediate vicinity, and plenty of convenience stores, which are the lifeblood of these hotels. The staff were very polite and helpful. Used the onsen, which, like the rest of the hotel, is very small. No towels are provided, so you have to bring your room towel, which is a rather annoying factor. The location is fantastic, and the promotional price of approximately USD240 per night within the norm for Tokyo. All in all, as expected, but not really compelling enough to want to return, unless in necessity.

Very good business hotel in Nihonbashi. New hotel so all rooms are still impeccable and all amenities new and functional. Did not have time to enjoy the public bath but looked very nice. Some nice shopping and restaurants in close proximity if you did not want to eat at the hotel. Their breakfast was interesting and very traditional Japanese although bacon and sausages are available for the less adventurous. Very good Bar and Barman with great selection of whisky. Will stay there again.

The hotel is right above 2 Metro Line and 1 JR Shin Nihonbashi station,Making this to be a very convent hotel.It also have a hot spring bath on 9th, making it more attractive!Did not have a chance to try the restaurant, because Not yet open.

Very nice room, just a bit little storage spaces for big bags. Very comfortable shower. Unfortunately no proper desk but comfortable chair and side table.Breakfast is a disaster, hardly any decent Western food and in general limited choices. But with a convenience store next door and cutlery and fridge in the room one can care for own food.Internet speed is rather poor for business purposes.

This hotel was very comfortable and the decor was amazing. The hotel actually starts from the 9th floor . The staff was very helpful. The rooms were good size considering it being in Japan, most hotels have small rooms. The service was incredible. Their pillows were the best.I would stay there again,
